name: Tesla, Inc.
goal:
Tesla’s mission is to accelerate the transition to sustainable energy. Founded in 2003, Tesla designs, manufactures and markets all-electric battery vehicles together with solutions for renewable energy production and storage. We want to be a catalyst for larger and broader investments in sustainable energy options.
All Tesla vehicles are 100% battery electric, with a driving range sufficient to completely replace internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles. Each generation of Tesla vehicles is one step further towards democratising electric cars as a genuine alternative to ICE vehicles – for short as well as long distance travelling. Starting with a sport car (Roadster, cumulative global sales 2,500), in 2018 we delivered over 245,000 vehicles, almost as many as we delivered in all prior years combined, becoming the world’s biggest electric vehicle manufacturer. 40% of deliveries were of our second generation of premium all-electric family vehicles (Model S and Model X), and 60% of our third-generation, and more affordable mass-market, ‘Model 3’. On 14 March 2019, we unveiled our next passenger car the Model Y. The global Tesla fleet has covered around 20bn electric kilometres.
Tesla Semi, a full-size heavy truck unveiled in November 2017, will have a transformative impact due total cost of ownership that is superior to diesel trucks. Tesla Semi combines a real-world range of up to 800km and has been designed to dramatically improve safety not only for the driver and cargo, but also for pedestrians, cyclists and other cars on the road.
Tesla is investing heavily in recharging infrastructure to create a no-compromise EV experience. Tesla’s pan-European motorway-charging network (“Supercharger Network”) enables EV customers to travel across Europe using only renewably sourced electricity. Early 2019, we operated 1,456 supercharger locations worldwide of which 438 (with 3,886 individual charging stalls) in Europe. This enables our customers to drive from the North of Norway to the South of Spain, while recharging times are about 30 minutes per 250 km driving range. Through our “Destination Charging” program, started in 2016, we are also supporting the larger tourism industry (hotels, restaurants, touristic resorts, etc.) in providing charging solutions for all EV users.
To support the development of renewably produced electricity, Tesla launched small and large-scale stationary battery storage solutions in 2015. For individual owners, Tesla’s “Powerwall” solution enables self-consumption of locally produced electricity or deferred electricity consumption to off-peak hours, as well as ensures continuation of supply in the event of a power failure. For industrial customers, Tesla’s “Powerpack” solution enables larger storage projects and grid services applications.
Tesla started delivering ‘solar roof’ solutions to enable renewable electricity production from people’s own roofs. Tesla’s solution is different from traditional solar panels: our solar tiles hide a photovoltaic cell within a true imitation of traditional roof tiles. Through the production of electricity, Tesla’s solar roof tiles will actually be cheaper than conventional roofs.
Tesla is headquartered in Palo Alto, California, USA, and employs over 40,000 people worldwide. Tesla’s main productions capacities are currently located in Fremont, California, Reno, Nevada and Buffalo, New York. In 2018 global revenue amounted $21.5bn/€19bn, up 82% from 2017.
Our European footprint is growing quickly. We operate an assembly facility in Tilburg, the Netherlands, and Tesla Grohmann Automation in Prüm, Germany, develops technologies for advanced manufacturing processes. Tesla´s European Headquarter is located in Amsterdam, Netherlands. We have around 5,000 employees across Europe and over 100 sales and service centres.
